problem.prob_desc:
23. $\lim\limits_{x \to 0} \dfrac{\ln(1 + 3x)}{\ln(1 + 5x)}$의 값은? [2점]
① $\dfrac{1}{5}$ ② $\dfrac{2}{5}$ ③ $\dfrac{3}{5}$ ④ $\dfrac{4}{5}$ ⑤ $1$

gpt-5-codex.title: Identify evaluation method
gpt-5-codex.body: As x approaches 0, both ln(1 + 3x) and ln(1 + 5x) approach ln 1 = 0, producing a 0/0 indeterminate form. For such expressions with logarithms near zero, using the series expansion ln(1 + ax) ≈ ax for small x will allow the limit to be evaluated.

gpt-5-codex.title: Compute limit via series
gpt-5-codex.body: Apply the expansion ln(1 + ax) ≈ ax. Then ln(1 + 3x) ≈ 3x and ln(1 + 5x) ≈ 5x. The ratio becomes (3x)/(5x), which simplifies to 3/5. Since higher-order terms vanish as x → 0, the limit equals 3/5.

gpt-5.title: Rewrite using standard limits
gpt-5.body: Rewrite the ratio to expose the standard limit ln(1+u)/u -> 1: ln(1+3x)/ln(1+5x) = [(ln(1+3x))/(3x)] * [3x/(5x)] / [(ln(1+5x))/(5x)] = (3/5) * [(ln(1+3x))/(3x)] / [(ln(1+5x))/(5x)].

gpt-5.title: Apply limit ln(1+u)/u → 1
gpt-5.body: As x → 0, 3x → 0 and 5x → 0, so (ln(1+3x))/(3x) → 1 and (ln(1+5x))/(5x) → 1. Therefore the whole expression tends to (3/5) * (1/1) = 3/5.

claude-opus-4.5.title: Identify the indeterminate form
claude-opus-4.5.body:
As x → 0:
- ln(1 + 3x) → ln(1) = 0
- ln(1 + 5x) → ln(1) = 0
This is a 0/0 indeterminate form, so we can apply L'Hôpital's rule or use the approximation ln(1 + u) ≈ u for small u.

claude-opus-4.5.title: Apply the logarithm approximation
claude-opus-4.5.body:
For small values of u, ln(1 + u) ≈ u.

As x → 0:
- ln(1 + 3x) ≈ 3x
- ln(1 + 5x) ≈ 5x

Therefore:
lim(x→0) [ln(1 + 3x)/ln(1 + 5x)] = lim(x→0) [3x/5x] = 3/5

gemini-3-pro.title: Rewrite expression using standard limit forms
gemini-3-pro.body:
To solve the limit $\lim_{x 	o 0} \frac{\ln(1 + 3x)}{\ln(1 + 5x)}$, we divide both the numerator and the denominator by $x$ to utilize the standard limit formula $\lim_{t 	o 0} \frac{\ln(1+t)}{t} = 1$. We then adjust the coefficients to match the specific arguments of the logarithms:
$$ \lim_{x 	o 0} \frac{\frac{\ln(1 + 3x)}{x}}{\frac{\ln(1 + 5x)}{x}} = \lim_{x 	o 0} \frac{3 \cdot \frac{\ln(1 + 3x)}{3x}}{5 \cdot \frac{\ln(1 + 5x)}{5x}} $$

gemini-3-pro.title: Evaluate limits and calculate result
gemini-3-pro.body:
Applying the property $\lim_{t 	o 0} \frac{\ln(1+t)}{t} = 1$ to both parts:
- Numerator: With $t=3x$, $\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\ln(1 + 3x)}{3x} = 1$.
- Denominator: With $t=5x$, $\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\ln(1 + 5x)}{5x} = 1$.

Substituting these values yields:
$$ \frac{3 \cdot 1}{5 \cdot 1} = \frac{3}{5} $$

grok-4-fast.title: Identify indeterminate form
grok-4-fast.body: As x approaches 0, ln(1 + 3x) approaches ln(1) = 0 and ln(1 + 5x) approaches 0, resulting in a 0/0 indeterminate form. Use the small-angle approximation for ln(1 + y) ≈ y when y → 0.

grok-4-fast.title: Apply approximation
grok-4-fast.body: ln(1 + 3x) ≈ 3x and ln(1 + 5x) ≈ 5x as x → 0. Thus, the limit is (3x)/(5x) = 3/5.
